meanings.definition: To bid more than the value or worth of something in an auction.
meanings.sent1: She overbid on the antique vase, paying much more than it was worth.
meanings.sent2: During the auction, he decided to overbid on the painting to ensure he would win.
meanings.sent3: The enthusiastic bidder accidentally overbid on a rubber duck, thinking it was a rare collectible.
meanings.sent4: In the heat of the moment, she overbid on the old book, caught up in the excitement of the auction.
meanings.sent5: His tendency to overbid on items at auctions became a running joke among his friends.

meanings.definition: To make a bid that is higher than someone else's bid.
meanings.sent1: He always tries to overbid his competitors to secure the winning bid.
meanings.sent2: In a bidding war, it's common for participants to overbid each other in their eagerness to win.
meanings.sent3: The siblings playfully overbid each other for the last cookie on the plate.
meanings.sent4: She strategically overbid her opponent in the final round of the auction, clinching the victory.
meanings.sent5: The auctioneer raised an eyebrow as the bidder continued to overbid without hesitation.

meanings.definition: To exceed the proper limit or boundary.
meanings.sent1: The construction project ended up overbudget because the contractor tended to overbid on materials.
meanings.sent2: It's important not to overbid your physical capabilities to avoid injuries during exercise.
meanings.sent3: The chef warned the trainee not to overbid on the salt in the recipe, as it could ruin the dish.
meanings.sent4: Her excitement caused her to overbid on the dance floor, leading to some clumsy missteps.
meanings.sent5: The team captain reminded the players not to overbid their energy reserves early in the game.
